form.steps:
1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, with a barbell on the floor in front of you. 
2. Hinge at your hips to grip the barbell with an overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. 
3. Keeping your back straight and core engaged, lift the barbell off the floor by extending your knees and hips. Once the barbell reaches your thighs, transition into the hang position by slightly bending your knees and pushing your hips back, allowing the barbell to hang just above your knees. This is the starting position. 
4. Explosively extend your hips and knees, pulling the barbell upward. As the barbell reaches chest height, shrug your shoulders powerfully to assist the upward movement. 
5. As the barbell continues to rise, quickly rotate your elbows forward and pull yourself under the bar, dropping into a quarter-squat position with your elbows high and pointing forward. 
6. Catch the barbell on your upper chest and shoulders, with your fingertips lightly touching the bar. 
7. Stand up completely, extending your legs and keeping the barbell stable. 
8. Lower the barbell back to the starting position with control by reversing the movement.

form.Grip: Overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.
form.Back: Keep your back straight throughout the entire movement. Avoid rounding your back.
form.Core: Engage your core muscles to maintain stability and protect your lower back.
form.Elbows: Keep your elbows high and pointing forward as you pull yourself under the barbell.
form.Feet: Keep your feet flat on the floor throughout the movement.
form.Head: Keep your head in a neutral position, looking straight ahead.

commonMistakes.Rounding the Back: This is a common mistake that can lead to lower back injury. Make sure to keep your back straight throughout the entire movement.
commonMistakes.Not Exploding Upwards: The hang clean requires a powerful and explosive upward movement. Don't try to lift the weight slowly or you'll lose momentum.
commonMistakes.Not Pulling Under the Bar: You need to quickly pull yourself under the barbell in order to catch it in the correct position. If you don't pull under, you'll likely miss the lift.
commonMistakes.Catching the Barbell on Your Fingers: The barbell should be resting on your upper chest and shoulders, not your fingers. If you're catching the barbell on your fingers, you're not getting under the bar properly.

comments.Full Body Exercise: The hang clean is a challenging and effective full-body exercise that works multiple muscle groups simultaneously.
comments.Power and Explosiveness: This exercise is great for developing power and explosiveness, which are important for many sports and activities.
comments.Technical Exercise: The hang clean is a technical exercise that requires practice and proper form. It's important to start with light weight and gradually increase the weight as you improve your technique.
comments.Progression: Once you've mastered the hang clean, you can progress to the full clean, which starts from the floor.

alternativesAndVariations.Power Clean: The power clean is a variation of the hang clean that starts from the floor. It's a more challenging exercise that requires more power and explosiveness.
alternativesAndVariations.Hang Snatch: The hang snatch is another Olympic weightlifting exercise that starts from the hang position. It's a more technical exercise than the hang clean and requires a wider grip.
alternativesAndVariations.Kettlebell Swings: Kettlebell swings are a great exercise for developing power and explosiveness in the posterior chain. They can be used as an alternative to the hang clean for those who are new to weightlifting.
alternativesAndVariations.Deadlifts: Deadlifts are a compound exercise that works many of the same muscle groups as the hang clean. They're a great exercise for building overall strength.
